name: Security Monitoring
description: You've set up IAM, encrypted your data, and locked down your network. But how do you know if something goes wrong? Security monitoring is how you keep an eye on everything—it's your early warning system. Think of it like this: locks on the doors are great, but you also need security cameras. In this topic, we'll set up the cameras for your Journal API.

learning_steps.description: Each cloud provider has two main monitoring services—one for performance metrics (CloudWatch, Azure Monitor, Cloud Monitoring) and one for audit trails (CloudTrail, Activity Log, Cloud Logging). You'll want to understand both. Read the overview for your provider.
These videos show real monitoring setups. The SIEM video is especially helpful if the concept is new to you—it explains how all the pieces fit together.
learning_steps.title: Security Monitoring in Practice

learning_steps.description: The NIST guide is the gold standard for incident handling, and the SANS guide covers monitoring patterns you'll see in real security operations. Worth a skim.

For your Journal API, here are the log sources that matter most:

- **Authentication Logs**: Who's logging in, when, and from where—catch brute force attempts
- **API Call Logs**: What actions are being performed on your cloud resources—spot unauthorized changes
- **Network Logs**: Traffic patterns—detect unusual connections to your database
- **Application Logs**: Your Journal API's own logs—errors, failed requests, suspicious patterns
- **Infrastructure Logs**: Changes to your cloud resources—know when someone modifies a security group

You can't alert on everything or you'll get buried in noise. Focus on these high-value signals for your Journal API:

- Failed authentication attempts (someone trying to guess passwords?)
- Unusual API call patterns (someone exploring your endpoints at 3 AM?)
- Network traffic anomalies (unexpected outbound connections from your database?)
- Resource configuration changes (who changed that security group?)
- Data access patterns (why is someone downloading all journal entries?)

SIEM (Security Information and Event Management) is how security teams see the full picture. It does four things:

1. **Collect** — Gather logs from all your services into one place
2. **Correlate** — Find patterns across different log sources ("this IP failed login AND then accessed the API AND then tried to reach the database")
3. **Alert** — Notify you when suspicious patterns are detected
4. **Investigate** — Give you tools to dig in and understand what happened

You might not need a full SIEM for your Journal API, but understanding the concept is important for real-world cloud engineering roles.

Bad alerts are worse than no alerts—if you get too many false alarms, you start ignoring them all. Here's how to build alerts that actually help:

- **High signal-to-noise**: Only alert on things that actually need attention
- **Actionable**: Every alert should tell you what to do about it
- **Escalation**: Different severity levels—a failed login doesn't need the same urgency as "all data is being exported"
- **Context**: Include enough info to start investigating without having to dig through three dashboards
